Hi Randy,

> If we can't quantify what we're trying to show, then what are =
we really showing? At that point, it's more of a proof of concept ("hey loo=
k! this works in my model!") than a contribution to scientific knowledge. P=
roofs of concept are great to see so people know we have it working, and ar=
e best presented as a poster or late-breaking abstract. A proof of concept =
by itself probably won't be enough content to properly fill a full-length p=
aper.
> 
> 
I'm not sure why you are assuming that all qualitative results =
are proof-of-concepts. I do think many proof-of-concepts are interesting (K=
en points out a great example in his reply to you), but the two are not equ=
ivalent. If I had a neural network that could paint in the style of Monet, =
reliably and repeatedly, and then I changed the model in some way and it pa=
inted in the style of Jackson Pollack repeatedly=85and then I changed it ag=
ain and it painted in the style of Van Gogh repeatedly, it wouldn't be a pr=
oof of concept, but it would be interesting! Likely such an experiment woul=
d reveal interesting things about the model and what produces vast differen=
ces in artistic style. But I might not be able to quantify the "monet-ness"=
, "van gogh-ness", or "pollack-ness" of the output=85or even that they are =
interestingly different...I'd have to rely on my human judgement to sense t=
hat there is a meaningful difference between the three different outputs. 
=


> In the example you bring up, what does the statement, "the 3D shapes pr=
oduced by CPPNs on EndlessForms [are] interestingly different from those pr=
oduced by L-Systems," actually tell us? I agree that such a statement would=
 be difficult to quantify because it is a hollow statement (which touches o=
n my section about hypothesis construction). What about the shapes makes th=
em interestingly different? What is it about the underlying architecture th=
at made the shapes interestingly different? Answering those questions would=
 lead to a quantitative measure out of necessity.
> 
> 

I completely disag=
ree with you. EndlessForms objects and Picbreeder images are less blocky an=
d have more subtle, nuanced regularities than L-Systems artifacts. They als=
o look more natural, at least with respect to producing animal forms.  How =
the two mutate differently also reveals the evolvability of the encoding (C=
PPNs accommodate more small, subtle changes while mutations to L-systems te=
nd to produce huge effects cascading throughout the phenotype and dramatica=
lly changing it). All of these observations tell us interesting things abou=
t the difference between the encodings and their evolvability, and suggest =
that the CPPN encoding likely captures some of the power of natural encodin=
gs (at least animal encodings).  

We could have an interesting conversatio=
n about these observation, and someone could even defend that L-systems are=
 more natural (e.g. they better resemble plants), but it's not the case tha=
t that conversation would be better had with numbers, or would be best sett=
led by a quantitative metric. The point is that until we invent true AI wit=
h similar pattern-recognition to humans, we don't have the ability to quant=
ify the recognition of interestingly different types of patterns even thoug=
h those differences are obvious to humans. This is the same reason why "mon=
et-ness" is pretty clear to us when we see it, but we can't quantify it wel=
l/easily. I should point out that I'm not saying that phenomena like "monet=
-ness" are not quantifiable in principle=85.eventually we will invent AI th=
at can "see" the world and recognize high-dimnsional clusters (like "monet-=
ness" and "pollack-ness" as different things, as well as quantify "naturaln=
ess") and at that point we probably can quantify these traits, but at prese=
nt we can't do that in a way that is ultimately helpful. If you are a revie=
wer and you force someone to try to quantify properties like "naturalness",=
 "monet-ness", etc., you are making things worse only in the name of claimi=
ng it's objective because it is quantitative. Your brain is simply better a=
t some things than our algorithms, and for those domains we should use our =
brains to evaluate the results, not numbers. Doing so doesn't make the stat=
ements "hollow", uninteresting, or unscientific. You will of course object =
that they are "subjective" judgements, and they are, but they are the best =
we've got and they can still be helpful. I will agree (in line with JBM) th=
at we should only accept such results when they are "obvious to us", so may=
be the claim "CPPNs are more natural than L-Systems" should be curbed by a =
reviewer, but something as obvious as "they are different" should not. 

> =
In short, if a statement can't be quantified, then it probably hasn't been =
refined enough.
> 
Do you still agree with this statement after my above ex=
amples? Surely you agree that Jackson Pollack paints in a different style t=
han Monet, but I'm guessing you also wouldn't insist on a quantitative meas=
ure before making that claim in a scientific publication. If you would insi=
st on that, then I think you are forgetting that quantitative measures are =
supposed to be tools that help advance scientific progress, not chains that=
 should bind us and slow us down. 

> > But we already know the result of t=
hat experiment. Ken has shown that target-based evolution doesn't work, so =
the error for target-based evolution will be non-zero (and likely large). B=
ut (as we mention in the paper) the error in our method can be tuned toward=
 zero by increasing the resolution of the workspace, so the error for the S=
eeded-CPPN technique effectively is zero. Thus, we know ahead of time that =
our method won't produce error. The only uncertainty is how bad target base=
d evolution would be, but that is not the focus of this paper, so the exper=
iment would be off-topic. In other words, we introduce a technique that eli=
minates the issue of error, since it skips right to the correct shape=85to =
compare it against an obviously bad technique that we know produces error w=
ould only be to satisfy reviewers that insist on quantification; it does no=
t address a broader hypothesis, no?
> 
> Sure, but those statements are a b=
it "cowboy science-y." Let me show you how those statements can (and likely=
 will) be translated:
> 
> "A single (non-reproduced?) study has suggested =
that targeted evolution does not work very well (with Picbreeder?). Our met=
hod can achieve an error of zero (data not shown).

Why do you say "(data n=
ot shown)"? Our paper does show with arguments and images that the error ca=
n be tuned toward zero by increasing the resolution. See the Super Mario fi=
gure and related text. 

> Thus, comparing our method with targeted evoluti=
on is pointless."
> 
> Performing such a quantitative comparison would kill=
 two birds with one stone: (1) it reproduces the findings that Ken made* in=
 a 3D domain, and (2) it would address the readers' concerns related to the=
 goal of the paper, particularly by directly showing that your method produ=
ces more accurate CPPN-based representations of 3D objects than the "leadin=
g" (only) method. For a methods paper, that is an important statement to ma=
ke. Thus, there is value in making a quantitative comparison here, and it's=
 not an arbitrary checkbox.
> 

If I invented a algorithm that provided the=
 optimal solution to any traveling salesmen problem every time, I wouldn't =
need to spend a huge chunk of the paper comparing it to every bad optimizat=
ion algorithm that has been thrown at the TSP over the years because the pr=
oblem would be solved. It would be enough to cite those papers and say that=
 they don't work well, especially as the difficulty (number of cities) incr=
eases, and then say "but now we have an entirely new method that doesn't re=
quire optimization and error: you can just skip right to the solution."

> =
It's a really bad assumption (that many of us make) that someone will want =
to follow up on our work. Yes, it's good to point out future research direc=
tions from the work, but the mindset that everyone will want to follow up o=
n our work can be damaging to the research field. Everyone wants to be the =
thought leader and establish a "new" research path, and that's why we see s=
o many people establishing new research platforms and whatnot every year an=
d talking about all the cool research that it enables. Then by the next yea=
r, that platform has fallen into obscurity because no one wanted to actuall=
y do that future work, and thus no one really learned anything from the pap=
er introducing that research platform.
> 

I agree with Ken that it is fine=
 to talk about the exciting future work that a paper enables/suggests. But =
even if you don't agree with that, what makes you conclude that I assume th=
at anyone else will follow up on the work? The future work section is about=
 work that could be done. If those possibilities are interesting, they rema=
in so even if no one follows up on them. In fact, if they are so  uninteres=
ting that no one would want to do them, then they certainly shouldn't be do=
ne and included in the original paper! It is only the work that you assume/=
believe someone would want to do that you should talk about! Moreover, I of=
ten write future work sections describing the work that I find interesting =
precisely because I plan to do it. Thus, I'm not assuming that someone else=
 will do it because I plan to do it myself. 

> That's a big reason why I t=
hink qualitative/methods/proof of concept  papers (whatever you want to cal=
l them -- they're the same) are not very useful to publish as full papers, =
and are better suited as a poster or late-breaking abstract.
> 

By that ra=
tionale you don't think the Picbreeder paper should have been published, or=
 Karl Sims work, is that right? The Picbreeder papers collectively have ove=
r 100 citations, and Sims' work arguably kickstarted/inspired the entire fi=
eld of artificial life and has thousands of citations. Picbreeder also visu=
ally demonstrates the power of CPPNs, provides an intuitive testbed for lea=
rning how they work, but also taught us lessons about Evolutionary Computat=
ion in general; the entire idea for novelty search emerged as a result of t=
he Picbreeder system! If your attitudes for what merits a publication were =
universal, no one would pursue this type of work because of the low value y=
ou place on it would mean that doing so would not help one's career, and th=
us such important work would not be done. I don't really get why we would w=
ant to eliminate such valuable work. So much crap gets published just becau=
se it has a few quantitative comparisons: I think we can spare a few paper =
slots for work that is interesting, yet not quantifiable. 

> 
> > I'm sorr=
y we didn't make it clear to you. Of course, that issue is also orthogonal =
to the quantitative vs. qualitative conversation, but it is something I wou=
ld like to address. Can you tell me what questions you have? I'd be happy t=
o try to answer them in this thread. If anyone reading this also has questi=
ons about the technique, please let me know. 
> 
> I think my main confusio=
n is the significance of the ds input to the CPPN. How does the CPPN end up=
 using that input? Why is that input useful for training a CPPN to reproduc=
e a predetermined 3D object?
> 


Thanks for your question. 

This comment =
reveals that we did fail to communicate the technique, because with the See=
ded-CPPN technique CPPNs are not trained in any way. It's possible that thi=
s misunderstanding contributes to your belief that the Seeded-CPPN techniqu=
e should be compared to target-based evolution, because if we were indeed w=
ere *training* CPPNs to reproduce an object then it would be more reasonabl=
e to require a comparison to alternate methods of training them to reproduc=
e the same object (i.e. target-based evolution). Note: the technique does a=
llow for *further* evolution of an arbitrary shape=85so evolutionary "train=
ing" does occur, but only after starting from the seed shape. 

With the Se=
eded-CPPN technique, you don't train the CPPN: you inject the geometry of t=
he seed object into the CPPN via the ds (distanceToSurface) input. For each=
 voxel, that ds input conveys the distance between that voxel and the surfa=
ce of the surface (outer shell) of the target object (along with a sign ind=
icating if that voxel is inside or outside the object). A CPPN recreates th=
e shape by filling in all voxels inside the shape, but the technique also a=
llows for warping of the object. For example, for a CPPN to increase the si=
ze of the target output similarly in all dimensions, it could find all voxe=
ls that are x centimeters away from, and outside of, the target object and =
fill them (and everything inside of them) in." For a CPPN to increase the w=
idth, but not the height, of an object, it could fill in the original objec=
t plus any voxels x cm away in the width-dimension, etc. Or it could do mor=
e complicated things based on the shape's geometry. Thus the CPPN can immed=
iately start from a desired pattern (in this case the shape of the object) =
and then elaborate on that shape by adding/subtracting from the original de=
sign, or by warping the original design. 

Does that make things clear? Ple=
ase let me know if you still have questions. 

Thanks again for the interes=
ting conversation,
Jeff


> 
> Cheers,
> Randy
> 
>

></div><div><br></div><div>Thanks for your question. </div><div><br></=
div><div>This comment reveals that we did fail to communicate the technique=
, because with the Seeded-CPPN technique CPPNs are not trained in any way. =
It's possible that this misunderstanding contributes to your belief that th=
e Seeded-CPPN technique should be compared to target-based evolution, becau=
se if we were indeed were *training* CPPNs to reproduce an object then it w=
ould be more reasonable to require a comparison to alternate methods of tra=
ining them to reproduce the same object (i.e. target-based evolution). Note=
: the technique does allow for *further* evolution of an arbitrary shape=85=
so evolutionary "training" does occur, but only after starting from the see=
d shape. </div><div><br></div><div>With the Seeded-CPPN technique, you=
 don't train the CPPN: you inject the geometry of the seed object into the =
CPPN via the ds (distanceToSurface) input. For each voxel, that ds input co=
nveys the distance between that voxel and the surface of the surface (outer=
 shell) of the target object (along with a sign indicating if that voxel is=
 inside or outside the object). A CPPN recreates the shape by filling in al=
l voxels inside the shape, but the technique also allows for warping of the=
 object. For example, for a CPPN to increase the size of the target output =
similarly in all dimensions, it could find all voxels that are x centimeter=
s away from, and outside of, the target object and fill them (and everythin=
g inside of them) in." For a CPPN to increase the width, but not the height=
, of an object, it could fill in the original object plus any voxels x cm a=
way in the width-dimension, etc. Or it could do more complicated things bas=
ed on the shape's geometry. Thus the CPPN can immediately start from a desi=
red pattern (in this case the shape of the object) and then elaborate on th=
at shape by adding/subtracting from the original design, or by warping the =
original design. </div><div><br></div><div>Does that make things clear=
? Please let me know if you still have questions. </div><div><br></div=
